sentences.sentence: Based upon this, however, I made this conclusion( 结论 ), that my only way to escape was to find a native.
If possible, it should be one of their prisoners, whom they had condemned( 定罪 ) to be eaten.
I decided, if possible, to get one of these natives, whatever the cost.
I watched to see them when they came on shore, and waited for my chance.
I waited more than a year and a half until I was surprised one morning to see no fewer than five boats all on shore together, on my side of the island.
The number of them frightened me greatly, for knowing that they always came four or six in a boat, I could not think how to attack twenty or thirty men on my own.
I climbed up to the top of the hill, and observed that they had a fire lit, and that they had meat prepared.
While I was thus looking on them, I saw two poor men dragged from the boats, where they were now brought out to be killed.
I saw one of them immediately fall, being knocked down with a club( 棍棒 ) or wooden sword.
Two or three others were at work immediately, cutting him open for their cookery.
The other victim was left standing by himself, till they should be ready for him.
In that very moment, this poor soul, seeing himself free and unbound( 无束缚的 ), ran directly towards me with incredible( 难以置信的 ) swiftness( 敏捷 ).
When I noticed him run to me, I was terribly frightened, especially when I thought I saw him chased( 追 ) by all the other natives.
However, when I found that only three men followed him, and that he ran much faster than them, I began to recover.
There was a stream between them and my cave, which I saw plainly he must swim over.
When the escaping native came there, he easily swam across in about thirty strokes( （游泳的）划水 ).
When the three men came to the stream, I found that two of them could swim, but the third could not.
I observed that the two who swam were stronger swimmers than the fellow who fled( 逃走 ) from them.
I realized that now was the time to get a servant.
I fetched my two guns and placed myself between the chasers( 追逐者 ) and the chased( 被追的人 ).
I called aloud to the man who fled( 逃走 ), and waved with my hand for him to come back.
Meanwhile, I slowly advanced towards the two that followed.
Rushing at once upon the closest native, I knocked him down with the handle of my gun.
After I knocked this fellow down, the other one behind him stopped, but I noticed he had a bow and arrow.
I was then forced to shoot at him first, which I did, and killed him with the first shot.
The poor remaining native, who had come back at my waving, was so frightened of my gun that he would come no closer.
I called again to him, smiled at him, and gave him all the signs of encouragement that I could think of.
Slowly he came nearer and nearer, kneeling( 跪 ) down every ten or twelve steps, in a sign of thanks for my saving his life.
Finally he came close to me, and then he laid his head upon the ground, and set my foot upon his head.
This, it seems, was a sign of swearing( 发誓 ) to be my slave forever.
But there was more work to do yet, for I noticed the native whom I had knocked down was not killed, but shocked with the blow.
So I pointed to him, to show my native that the man was not dead.
Upon this he spoke some words to me, and though I could not understand them, they were the first sound of a man’s voice that I had heard for more than twenty-five years.
My native made a sign to me that I should lend him my sword, and in one stroke( 一挥剑 ) cut off the man’s head.
When he had done this, he came laughing to me in a sign of victory, and brought me the head of the native that he had killed.
He made signs to me that he should bury the dead men under the sand, and so I made signs to him again to do so.
He fell to( 开始做某事 ) work, and I believe he had buried them both in a quarter of an hour. Then I took him back to my cave.
He was a handsome fellow, with straight, strong arms and legs.
I guess he was about twenty-six years of age. He had a very good appearance, and a very manly face.
Yet he had all the sweetness and softness of a European, especially when he smiled.
His hair was long and black, but not curled( 卷曲的 ) like wool, and his forehead very high and large.
The color of his skin was not quite black, but of a bright kind of an olive( 橄榄色的 ) color.
After he had slept about half an hour, he awoke again, and came out of the cave to me.
I began to speak to him, and teach him to speak to me.
First, I let him know his name would be Friday, which was the day I saved his life.
I also taught him to say Master, which was what he would call me.
I fed( 喂养 ) him, and gave him some clothes, for he was completely naked( 赤身裸体的 ).
As we went by the place where he had buried the two men, he pointed exactly to the place, making signs to me that we should dig them up again and eat them.
At this I appeared very angry, and waved with my hand to him to come away.
He did immediately, with great shame.
I then led him up to the top of the hill, to see if his enemies were gone.
I saw plainly the place where they had been, but no sight of them or their boats, so that it was clear they were gone.

The next day after I came home with him, I made a smaller tent for him. I closed the entrance to my cave in the night, so that Friday could in no way attack me. But I needed none of all this protection, for never has a man had a more faithful, loving, sincere( 真诚的 ) servant than Friday was to me. I believed he would have sacrificed( 牺牲 ) his life to save mine if needed.
I now made it my business to teach him everything that was proper to make him useful, especially to make him speak, and understand me when I spoke. He was the smartest student that ever was.

question.cn: 那个可怜的人没被绑住的时候，他做了什么？
question.en: What did the poor man do when he was unbound?

analysis: 文中说：“In that very moment, this poor soul, seeing himself free and unbound, ran directly towards me with incredible swiftness.”所以选C。

question.cn: Robinson为什么要救那个逃跑的土著人？
question.en: Why did Robinson save the escaping native?

options.cn: 因为那个土著人很帅，Robinson很喜欢他。
options.en: Because he was handsome and Robinson liked him.
Because Robinson wanted to get a servant.
Because Robinson wanted to find someone to talk with.

analysis: 文中说：“I realized that now was the time to get a servant.”接下来他就准备好武器去救那个逃跑的土著人了，所以选B。

question.cn: Robinson救了的那个土著人是怎么杀掉另一个土著人的？
question.en: How did the native that Robinson saved kill the other native?

options.en: He shot him with a gun.
He cut off his head with a sword.

analysis: 文中说：“My native made a sign to me that I should lend him my sword, and in one stroke cut off the man’s head. . . and brought me the head of the native that he had killed.”所以选C。

question.cn: Robinson救的那个土著人懂英语吗？
question.en: Did the native Robinson saved know any English?

analysis: 根据文中描述，从Robinson救他，到后面的活动都是用手势进行交流的，只是到了后来Robinson才教他说英语， 所以选B。

question.cn: Robinson给他救的土著人起了什么名字？
question.en: What did Robinson name the native he saved?

analysis: 文中说：“I let him know his name would be Friday.”所以选A。
